title: Dubai Insiders on What to Explore—and What to Love—in the Ever-Changing City
text:
Butheina Kazim is the founder of Dubai’s Cinema Akil, the only arthouse movie theater in the Arab Gulf and part of a network of independent cinemas presenting alternative narratives across the Arabic-speaking world. The single-screen theater, located in the city’s industrial Al Quoz neighborhood, also hosts occasional open-air screenings that can attract up to 1,000 people from all walks of life. As a result, Ms. Kazim is nominated for an Emirates Woman 2019 Award for arts and culture.

Photo: Faisal Tannir / Rouya PR

What She Loves:

“It’s a very ambitious city through and through, and kind of a conveyor belt due to its large expatriate population. I’m 35 and I’ve seen so many people come in and out. You get used to people both coming here with their own tragedies, and you get used to people leaving all of the time. There’s a unity through the transience.

“I’ve spent time in Canada and New York, but I came back. I’ve been in and out of the city my whole life. There has been tremendous change that I’ve both mourned and celebrated.

“The area I grew up in, Jumeirah, used to be mainland but now it's an island. The new Dubai canal project connected Dubai Creek through to the Gulf and suddenly that whole area became an island, let alone all of the new development.

“There have been a lot of bizarre changes, some exciting or funny, others somehow painful because the memories you rooted yourself to and connected with growing up are gone. For instance, when Golden Cinema, the biggest standalone cinema in the city, closed we took the theater seats to Cinema Akil. People try to hold onto the nostalgia.

Insider Tips:

“I grew up most of my life in Al Satwa, one of the older neighborhoods in Dubai. It’s a mixed community of older buildings that I would call ‘ugly beautiful.’

“Cinema Akil is in an area called Al Quoz, which is an industrial zone with export facilities and warehouses. It looks something like how New York City’s Meatpacking District looked at one point, or Dumbo [in Brooklyn] without the residential component. It started with a few galleries, who took charge turning it into an arts community. At first, they were not consolidated and you had to really wander around getting lost in this area of warehouses.

“It brings together everything from a coffee roastery of the hipster variety to an independent bookstore. There’s the community theater, The Junction, and the record store, The Flipside, which happens to be our neighbor.

Alserkal Avenue (in Al Quoz) is also one of the very few dog friendly areas in the city.”
description: A reality TV judge, a top chef and an advocate for the independent art scene on their favorite places in the UAE city
